div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,589] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray’s Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO. MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, MANSOURAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital £ 1.500,000
Reserve Fund '' 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial houses and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 3 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deposited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 13-9-906

div.head: The Planets
div.p: Mercury is a morning star but becomes invisible towards the end of this month
Venus is an evening star visible for about 2 hours after sunset.
Mars is a morning star throughout the month
Jupiter rises shortly before midnight.
Saturn is in opposition and is therefore visible all night.
The chief constellations in the South at 9 p.m. are Delphinus, near the zenith, and Capricornus at an elevation of 45°

div.head: THE TURKISH SUCCESSION.
div.p: For some weeks there have been mysterious rumours of the possibility of an attempt to change the succession to the Turkish Throne. The most persistent is that it is the desire of Abdul Hamid to appoint his third son, Prince Burhaneddin, as his successor, and for this purpose to obtain the consent of the Sheik-ul- Islam and of the Ambassadors of the Great Powers. It is even added that Abdul Hamid is thinking of abdicating in favour of this Prince.

The rumoured step would (the Constanti- nople correspondent of the "Tribune" think) be an exceedingly grave one. It is probable that any attempt to make such a change without the consent of the ulema class, of whom the Sheik-ul-Islam is the head, would fail, and might simply plunge the coyntry into revolution. It is further rumoured that the Sheik-ul-Islam has been sounded, and that he has declared that such a change could never be sanctioned.This, however,we do not believe.
Rumour farther says that the German Emperor has been asked for his counsel, and that the sudden return here, a week ago, of the German Ambassador is in connexion with this question.

While fully admitting that we are dealing only with rumours, these are so persistent-and definite as to suggest that they have a basis of truth, and the questions raised by them become interesting and important.

The Moslem law of succession to a royal throne is bated upon long usage, and enacts that tae heir is the eldest male in the Royal or Imperial family. A simple illustration is furnished by the recent history of Egypt. When Mehmet Ali became by Imperial firman and the recognition of Europe, Vice-Roy of Egypt, the Sultan issued a firman in 1846 by which the successions was to be regulated in the Moslem fashion, that is, the heir was always to be the eldest male descended from Mehmet Ali. The rule was strictly followed till the time of Ismail. On the death of Ismail the legal heir to the Khedival throne should have been Prince Halim, the youngest son of Mehmet ALi. But Ismail, in 1866. by means of very heavy payments, had induced Abdul Aziz, the Sultan of Turkey (who was deposed and "suicided” in 1876), to grant a new firman, by which the succession was changed from the Moslem to the general European system of succession.

When the representatives of England and France decided in 1870 to get rid of Ismail, they secretly, but unmistakably, gave him the opportunity to leave Egypt quietly, in which case the firman which be had obtained would be recognized, and his son allowed to reign in his stead. If he refused, Hahim, the “de jure" heir by Moslem law, would be placed on the throne. He agreed to go quietly. It was generally believed in Stamboul that Abdul Aziz, in granting the firman changing the Egyptian succession, had the intention to change the succession to the Turkish throne. In such case Prince Yussouf Izzedin would have been the heir-apparent. The revolution of 1876 put an end to any such design, and Murray, and then the present occupant, were girded with the sword of Osman in confor- city with the well-established rule. At the time, however, when the project of changing the Ottoman rule of succession was in the air, it was well understood that the ulema class were strongly opposed to it. They represent the conservative element of Islam ; and unless some very special circumstances should be brought forward, they would oppose a stout resistance to any change of the kind.

The present heir to the throne is Reshad Effendi, the Sultan’s brother. Both he and Izzedin and two elder brothers rank, on the ground of age, before the third son of the present Sultan. The supposed favorite of his Majesty for the succession in his third son, who is known to the Ambassadors as a bright and intelligent young man of about twenty years old. The question is mainly, though not exclusively, of course, one for the subjects of his Majesty, and especially for his Moslem subjects. If the change is attempted, it will probably give rise to considerable trouble.

The suggestions that Abdul Hamid would be willing to abdicate does not strike me as probable. Those who are in favor of his doing so speak disparagingly of Reshad Effendi ; but there will be always a party strongly in his favor as representing the reign of Moslem law. There are precedents for passing over the heir, but the change has always been regarded as revolutionary.

Though, of course, the personality of the Sultan is for foreign States as a matter of great importance, the representatives of such States will probably best consult the interests of their Governments, and certainly of Turkey, by having nothing to do with any proposal to change the succession. The fact that they or any of them favoured one candidate more than another would do much to make him unpopular with the Moslem population. The matter is primarily one for the Moslem people of Turkey, and for a foreign Government to pronounce an opinion one way or another would have the appearance of mixing in a Palace intrigue.

If it be said that Turkey is more of less under European tutelage, and that the unanimous consent of Europe to a change of Moslem law would give it a sanction which would secure its general acceptance, our reply would be that unanimity on this subject is impossible, and to attempt to obtain it would occasion endless intrigue. It may be admitted that if the general consent of Europe could be obtained it might establish an important precedent. But if such consent has been applied for, and if, as is rumored, negotiations are going on, it is because opposition is anticipated either by Turkey or by some foreign State. Even an attempt by the Concert of Europe would be denounced by the Moslem population as an interference by the gainers with their religious rights.

There is much to be said for and much against the alleged project. The generally- expressed opinion is that certain Palace favou- rites, for their own purposes, are in its favor, and this would not recommend it to the Turkish population, and still less to Europeans. Indeed, in whatever way the expediency of a change in the law of succession may be regar- red, its practical application will be dangerous. It will almost certainly lead to disturbances, and it ought to be a question for Turkish statesmen whether it is desirable to add to the many difficulties with which they have to deal a possible war of succession. For foreign States the question is at once tempting and dange- rous. In the solution of the many questions in the Near East with which our country is con- corned, it is difficult to see what advantage could be gained by entering upon it. Sir Edward Grey will probably conclude that his wisest course is to reserve speech or action, and take up the position that Great Britain will stand aloof, and neither approve nor disprove any action of the kind which the Palace advisers may choose to take.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Agricultural School
A veterinary professor is to be attached to the School of Agriculture, Cairo.
Damanhour Station.
Damanhour is to have a larger station, and the extension it to cost L.E. 6,600
Brindisi Mall
The Brindisi mail viâ Port Said will be distributed at Alexandria tomorrow at 4:45 p.m.
The Yacht Dragon.
Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan’s yacht, the Dragon, sailed yesterday for Constantinople.
New Doctors.
Drs. Vittorio Acco, Pozzolla Giuseppe, and Jean B. Petri, have been authorised to practise as doctors of medicine in Egypt.
A Bullion Cargo.
The P. and O. Company’s steamer Oriental, which is due at Port Said shortly, has bullion on board to the value of 1,010,000 rupees.
New Professors.
The new professors for the Ministry of Public Instruction appointed by Mr. Dunlop will arrive here towards the end of this month.
White Nile.
The dredging operations on the White Nile will commence after the flood, and several American machines will be used for the purpose.
Hashish.
The Government intend prohibiting the growth of the opium poppy in Egypt The variety known as Theban opium yields 10 to 12 per cent of morphine.
Alhambra Theatre.
The Carlo Lombardo Operatic troupe is shortly expected here and will give a series of twenty representations. Books of 10 coupons of P.T. ICO are available.
Another Cambling Den Raided.
A raid was made on Sunday night at Cairo, on a house in the Darb el Mebellat. The gambling paraphernalia were confiscated, and a summons issued against the owner.
Murkaz Court officials
The Ministry of Justice has appointed Mulaz m Awal Ali Eft. Ahmed and Mahmoud Eff. Inayet, officers in the Canal Gouvernorat, to act as parquet officials before the Markaz Courts.
The Plague.
One death from bubonic plague was notified at Alexandria yesterday. A native, living in the Menshieh quarter, was found dead at his own house. To-day's bulletin shows no fresh case.
Egypt and Wireless Telegraphy.
The Egyptian Government has delegated Mr. Schreiber, of the Telegraph Department, to represent it at the forthcoming Interna- tional Wireless Telegraphic Conference.
Cotton Worm.

A further batch of 32 moawens and ton clerks, superintending the work of destroying the cotton boll worm, have been discharged in view of the disappearance of the parasite, thanks to the methods employed.
Maltese National Fete.

The Maltese Philharmonic Society of Alex- andria, “La Valletta,” will celebrate the anniversary of the National Fete on Saturday next by a grand ball, which will be held at the headquarters of the Society, Via ler Khedive 83.
The Shoubra Crime.

No convincing evidence has as yet been brought forth to prove the guilt of the young Frenchman who has been arrested on the charge of the brutal murder of M. Scopelidis at Shoubra, but, at the same time, the accused remains under detention at the French Consu- late, the circumstantial evidence being, we understand, too strong to permit of his release on bail.
Ritz Hotels.

A new Company, to be known as the Egypt- ian Ritz Hotels, has just been floated in Paris. It will start with an hotel at Kasr el Doubara, on land owned by the Nile Land Company. The manager of this hotel will be M. Pfiffer, who is well known in Egypt. The company has a capital of £150,000. The preliminary negotiations were very ably con- ducted by M. J. Mondolfo.
Village Murder

Early on Saturday morning three persons broke into a house of a native at Karakis village, Damanhour markaz, and shot him in the breast, causing a severe wound. The man is now in Damanhour hospital in a precarious condition. Two of the ruffians have been arrested, and the police have left for that village which is ten kilometres from Daman hour in search for the third.
Cairo’s Eastern Suburbs.

In order to extend its electric light service to Koubbeh, Zeitoun, and Matarieh, the Cairo Gas Company have applied to the Ministry of Public Works for permission to enlarge their transformation plant at Zaher, and to use for that purpose the interior of the mo qua of Zaher. The Ministry approves of the demand, but must consult with the Society for the Preservation of Arab Monuments.

div.head: Sudan Government.
div.p: NOTICE.

Persons importing Egyptian Labourers to work in the Sudan are recommended to entre into a written contract with them. This contract should be explained and signed by the Labour- ers in presence of an official or other reliable witness.28283A-30-10-906

div.head: WEATHER IN ENGLAND.
TROPICAL HEAT-
div.p: London, September 3.

Great Britain has been visited by an unpre- cedented heat wave. The thermometer register- ed over ninety degrees in the shade for several days. Football players and spectators have, in several cases, been carried off in a state of prostration. On Saturday the hospital at Northampton took fire : it is believed to have been caused by the rafters becoming ignited by the sun's rays. There were many cases of corn stacks, petroleum tanks, trees, etc., being set on fire. (Reuter)
THE RUSSIAN HORRORS.
St. Petersburg, September 3.
Riot, fire, and conflict was the programme of yesterday in several provincial towns. (H.)
Odessa, September 3.
A military terrorist organisation has been discovered. Fourteen officers and an army sur- geon have been arrested. (Havas)

div.head: THE OTTOMAN ARMY.
BIG REMOUNT ORDER.
div.p: Constantinople, September 3.
The Minister of War has decided to pur- chase a thousand horses for the artillery and cavalry. (Havas)

div.head: AMERICAN WARSHIPS.
A RECORD GATHERING.
div.p: New York, September 3.
President Roosevelt reviewed in Oyster Bay the greatest fleet of American warships ever assembled, numbering 43 in all. (Reuter)

div.head: MR BRYAN'S CAMPAIGN.
A FATAL POLICY.
div.p: New York, September 3.

Mr. Bryan’s advocacy of the State ownership of railways is considered as seriously jeopar- dising his chances of being elected to the Presidency. Powerful influences are now agitating for President Roosevelt's re-election. (Reuter)

div.head: ENGLISH SPELLING
ROOSEVELT’S PROVISIONS.
div.p: Washington, September 3.
President Roosevelt says that if the simpli- fied spelling now used in public documents meets with general approval it will be made permanent, but if otherwise it will be dropped. (Reuter)

div.head: SOUTH AFRICA.
A LOAN OF £4,000,000.
div.p: London, September 3.

The Government, through Lord Selborne, has suggested that the Transvaal and Orange River Colonies should raise a loan of £4,000,000, guaranteed by the mining houses, to be spent for the sole benefit of those colonies. This is to replace the mine owners’ liability in the £30,000,000 war loan, the Imperial Govern- ment being desirous of eliminating contro- versial subjects from South Africa. (Reuter)

div.head: JAPANESE SEAL POACHERS.
FIVE MORE ARRESTS.
div.p: New York, September 3.
Five Japanese have been arrested in the act of seal poaching off St. George’s Island. They declare that they were merely landing in search of water. (Reuter)

div.head: POLAR EXPEDITION.
NORTH WEST PASSAGE ATTAINED.
div.p: New York, September 3.
The Norwegian Polar Expedition vessel Gjoa has reached Nome (Alaska), thus com- pleting the north-west pasaage. (Reuter)

div.head: THE PREMIER
div.p: London, September 3.
Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman bas arrived, accompanying the body of Lady Bannerman. {Reuter)

div.head: RESCUE FROM TURKISH DUNGEONS.
AN EGYPTIAN’S ADVENTURE
"BEWARE OF ARIF!"
div.p: The reason that led to the extraordinay arrest of Mahmoud Arif Bey, an Egyptian and a Wakil of the Wakfs Administration, as soon as he had landed in Stamboul, ire now revealed. Before he sailed by the Kahira for Constanti- nople,the following telegram was sent by one of the Turkish cabal to Tewfik Pasha, the Ottoman Foreign Minister -"Mahmoud Arif has left for Stamboul. He is an emissary of the Young Turks. Beware!”

Great was the excitement in the Bawab Aali on receipt of this startling news, and a number of the hafieh (or secret police) were posted at various points along Galata Quay on the moment of the arrival of the Khedivial Mail Liner “El Kahira.”

Aril Bey, all the time unconscious of what was awaiting him, had risen early to admire the beauties of the Bosphorus, the prospect of which with its delicious gold-spangled waters and fairy-like retreats made him long to be ashore. He was the first at the gangway, and was just stepping onto quay when the order tut! (seize) was given, and before Aril Bey knew where he was, be found himself in a closed araba with two policemen on either side, driving rapidly over Galata Bridge to the Grand Zaptieh, the grim dungeon which is reserved for Armenians and political offenders. Without a word of explanation, or apology, he was hustled unceremoniously into a dark and loathsome cell, and there confined. Unfortuna- tely he had left his money behind, and without means, he lived on the coarse prison bread, and putrid water for some days during which he was allowed to see no one, although he begged the zaptieh in charge to convey a note to Bebek.

As chance would have it, the kavass of the Khedivial Palace, who had boarded the Kahira for the mails, had seen Mahmoud Bey Arif carried off to Stamboul, and he lost no time in taking the first Shirket steamer to Bebek, and informed the secretaries of the case.

All praise is due to Izzet Bey, the President of the Khedivial Court, who moved heaven and earth to get Arif Bey released ; had it not been for him Arif Bay might long have languished in his Turkish cell.
Arif Bey, who is in his prime, is no Young Turk: he is on the contrary an ardent Nationalist, and most popular. His arrest made quite a stir amongst the nation and press.

We have already advocated the need for the proper recognition of the Egyptian nationality in Turkey, by means of a Kapu Kethudassi, or Diplomatic Agency, with powers similar to those of the Bulgarian Agent. Dependent on that also is the question of a Habeas Corpus for the Khedive's subjects.

div.head: CONSTITUTION FOR TURKEY.
div.p: Mohamed Bey Wahid, a Cairo notable, has addressed the following telegram to the Sultan on the occasion of his Accession anniversary:—
A Sa Majesté le Grand Kalife.

“Au nom de tons les Egyptiens impartiax, libéraux, et fidèles au trone du Khalfe, j'adresse mes vœux de félioitations k Vote Majesté pont Votre benrenx anniversaire, ft je vous supplie de promulguer un iradé pour octroyer la Constitution, et cela par pitié pour mes frères ottomans, qui vivent sous las ailis de Votre misérioorde et par l'intérêt jalous que je ressens poor la gloire de Votre grand empire et afin que la Poissanœ ottomane te soit pas en arrière des autres Paissances orien- tales qui l’ont devancés par le chemin de la Constitution.

div.head: KAMEL AGAIN.
div.p: "Al-Zaher’s” correspondent at Alexandria writes :

Formerly, in my comments upon the Denish- wai affair I mentioned that the Intelligence Department, Cairo, inquired, during the past summer into the political aims of Mustapha Pasha Kamel, and the reasons of his depar- ture for Berlin where he arranged to meet the German authorities ; and also as to the functionary who provided him with letters of introduction enabling him to have private meetings with high German officials. Readers also remember my remarks on Lord Cromer's statement published in the White Book to the effect that “there are in Egypt some parties who are planning plots against the present Government, with the assistance of one or two foreign Governments.” It was therefore not without reason that the “Temps" accused Mustapha Pasha Kamel of working together with Baron von Oppenheim in the interests of Turkey, Against the Egyptian Government. However, as a matter of fact, we ought to do the Pasha justice by removing the charge preferred against him, for, as the "Moayad" said, we believe that he serves his country rashly and that he does not repre- sent any party in Egypt. On the other hand Mastapha Pasha Kamel is not the man to fulfil such an important position in this country, which is not yet full grown in civilisa- tion, and even if the soul of Garibaldi himself were to be transmigrated into Mustapha Kamel he would fail to find around him three Egyptians ready to obey his orders. Moreover, the Pasha is a wily young man, enlightened, acquainted with law and does not ignore the strength and influence of the British Occupation in Egypt. He it too intel- ligent to ignore also the consequences of agreeing with foreign governments or official in order to conspire against his own govern- ment.

div.head: THE LATE PRINCE IBRAHIM.
THE PORTUGAL’S ARRIVAL
div.p: The mortal remains of Prince Mohamed Bey Ibrahim arrived at Alexandria by the Messageries Maritimes S.S. “Portagal” this morning. A special train will convey the body to Cairo at 4 o’clock this afternoon.

The Prince’s widow, the Princess Saliha Haiem, Prince Ibrahim Pasha Hilmi, Prince Ibrahim Pasha Halim, Prince Fazil Osman, and Mr Nasri Tagir, the late Prince's secretary, arrived by the same steamer, and were met by Prime Omar Pasha Tounsoun, Prince Haidar, and Said Zulficar Bey, the Khedive's master of ceremonies.
Prince Mohamed Aly Pasha, who arrived from Europe yesterday in order to represent the Khedive at Prince Mohamed Bey Ibrahim’s funeral, proceeded to Cairo in a special saloon yesterday evening.
The Khedive has also delegated Ahmed Chefik Bey and Said Zulficar Bey to represent him.

The Prince’s widow bas given frs. 200,000 to the widow of the chauffeur Doranson. The value of the estate of the late Prince Mohamed Bey Ibrahjm is estimated at £5,000,000, besides a life assurance, for £1,000,000, which the Prince contracted last year.

div.head: THE COMMERCIAL INDUSTRIAL AND LAND COMPANY OF EGYPT.
div.p: This Company has decided not to take over the business of Mr. Edgar Kirby and Co., of Alexandria and Cairo.
The Company had originally five options :

The firm of R. Kuster & Co., engineers, ionfounders, contractors to the Government, tie railways, and gas and water Companies. The firm of Edgar Kirby & Co., of Alaxan- dria, Cairo, and Mansourah, Government con- tactors, sanitary engineers, and general merchants.

The business of Murdoch & Templeton, contraotors, engineers, boilermakers, mill- wrights, &c, with works within a few yards of the Nile, and adjascent to the railway, and conprising business premises, residential houses-—all freehold, and containing 5,197 square metres.
The Mansourah Electric Light Concession, which was granted by the Municipality of Musourah in the year 1899.

A Freehold Building Site, situate on the Island of Rodah, containing some 14,400 square metres of land (over three acres). Of the above options the only one which it has been decided to exercise is that of R. Kuster and Co. This firm’s position has been met carefully investigated by Messrs. Russell, Ker and Wyatt.

There have been various rumours current as to a hitch having arisen in regard to the deve- lopment of the Company, but we are author- ised to state that there has been no "contre- temps" of any sort or kind and the Company has every prospect of a successful future, as the form of Kuster and Co. is one of the soundest in Egypt. It is the intention of the Company to take over any other businesses, which it is thought will be profitable investments.
Mr. Louis Sinclair, the Managing Director of the Company,will arrive in Egypt in October.

div.head: ENTERPRISE & DEVELOPMENT CO.
div.p: Oar Beyrout correspondent writes : —

The allied scheme of the Uzai garden-city continues to be the order of the day, and seems to have enlisted the interest of serious and important Anglo-Egyptian Companies. Habib Bey Ghanem and Salim Bey Shakir, who are said to have been delegated by the Enter- prise and Development Company to treat with Ibrahim Tabet Bey, have obtained from the latter an option for the purchase of his vast domain in Uzai, which amounts to over three million square meters. The terms of this preliminary agreement, which are advantageous to both parties, are subject to the ratification of the Directors at Cairo, the extreme limit of the option being the middle of October next, when the important section of the Egyptian business world ret- urns from their summer holiday. Knowing the principal terms of the agreement, I may say that the Company may be congratulated on the good deal it has made through its capable delegates above mentioned.

div.head: SAN STEFANO NEW THEATRE
div.p: We remind our readers of the entertainment thiss evening at 9.30 for the benefit of the Della Rocoa Ballet. The staging effects will be great- ly enhanced by electric light and the repertoire of the Philharmonic Band is select.

On Thursday, at 5.30, there is a grand concert for vocal and instrumental parts. On Friday a symphonic concert at 5.30 and children’s dance, and on Saturday, at 5.30, grand concert by the Bracale orchestra.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. “Scottish Prince,” with passengers and a general cargo, left Manchester on the 2nd inst and is due at Alexandria on or about the 19th inst.

div.head: MENZALEH CANAL COMPANY.
PROGRESS AND PROSPECTS.
div.p: A Port Said correspondent writes :—

The returns of the Lake Menzaleh, Canal Company average about £5 a day from pas- senger and cargo traffic. This average of receipts is considerably less than the cost of running the steamboats. Until the canal is carried right to the Suez Canal there is little prospect of the carriage of cotton being made payable, as at present the steam boats have to be unloaded at Karputi and thence the cargo has to be brought by train to Port Said. The tram service is not what it ought to be, being merely dependent on horse traction.

When the Menzaleh Canal opens right into the Suez Canal it may be greatly improved. But at present they have not commenced to make the connection. With regard to the development of passenger traffic from Port Said in the summer, to encourage people to take the trip to Matarieh, it will be necessary to build an hotel there, as at present there is no accommodation for travellers Unless the company completes the canal as originally intended and opens the service right out to Damietta and thence connects it with the Nile there is not much chance of a dividend being paid on the working. I interviewed a resident here, who made the trip on the first steamer which which went to Matarieh on the 31st December last, and he told me that there was considerable dissatisfaction owing to the difficulties of navigating in the narrow channel. Moreover the steamers were found to draw too much draught in the shallow lake. He also informed me that they struck several times on a sand bank, and as a matter of fact could not return to Port Said by the steamer that night. However it is thought that after the Canal is completed and connection estab- lished with the Suez Canal the service will be much better patronized and the present work- ing expenses reduced. Mr. Davison, the new engineer, is carrying out certain improvements such as deepening the channel, which will con- siderably facilitate the passage, which ought to average only three hours from the Suez Canal to Matarieh.

Already the natives have begun to use the steam boats, but so far it has not been taken up much for the transit of merchandise in large quantities. The boats used are of the stern wheel type designed by Shilston and originally suggested for traffic on the Nile by Mr. Thubron. From what I have learned Mr. Shitston, who was originally in Cook's ser- vice, but left that company to commence a new service which ultimately became the Anglo-American Nile Company, was the man who really bad technical knowledge of boat building and designed most of the present steamers on the Nile. He it now connected with the Nile Flotilla Company and Mr. Porter has taken his place in the Hamburg Anglo- American Company. Sir John Rogers is deeply interested in the Menzaleh Canal Company and consequently it is probable that it will be pushed on with, and that in time it will become a payable concern. But that will not be for a few years yet, unless they develope the business much faster.
Consequently it will be advisable to suspend any judgment as to the reseats future prospects of the company.
The idea of the Merzaleh Canal was to deflect some of the cotton exports from Alex- andria to Port Said. At present, however, there is no immediate prospect of any such idea being realised.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA HARBOUR.
div.p: The small buoy which was laid down on the S.E. edge of the bank with least depth of 13 feet lying to the West of the breakwater end (notice to mariners 27. 6. 05) has been removed and will not again be replaced.

Mariners are again cautioned not to pass between the breakwater and and the Pivot Gas Buoy, as the water is rapidly shoaling, on account of the large amount of spoil which has been deposited between these points.

div.head: CHARTS FOR EGYPTIAN WATERS.
div.p: Chart 3492 Sheikh el Barghut (Port Sudan) on a scale of 9 in.= 1 nautical mile, face value (unbacked) 2/6, and Chart 3567 Marsa Matruh, on a scale of 14 in. = 1 nautical mile face value (unbacked) 2 s. have now been pub- blished by the British Admiralty.
Chart 3119 Alexandria Harbour has been brought up to date, showing all the completed works and those in course of construction.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Daring the week which ended last Saturday only four cases of plague were notified in Egypt, all of which occurred at Alexandria. Two cases were found dead and two died in hospital, while five cures are reported. The number remaining under treatment is two. Since the 1st January the total number of cases notified amounts to 438, as compared with 216 and 786 daring tbs corresponding years of 1905 and 1904 respectively.

div.head: MEN-OF-WAR AT SUEZ
div.p: (From our Correspondent)
Suez, September 3.
H.M S. first-class cruiser “Argonaut" arrived at Suez this morning from the South, and entered the Canal at noon, homeward bound. H.M.S. "Proserpine" is expected to arrive at Suez to-day.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H..H. PrinceHussein Kamel Pasha is ex- pected to return from Europe on the 15th inst.
The Countess of Cromer, who has been taking the waters at Carlsbad, is passing a few days with Sir Hugh and Lady Alice Shaw-Stewart at Ardgowan House. Renfrew- shire.

Among the passengers who arrived at Alex- andria yesterday by the North German Lloyd steamer “Hohenzollern" from Marseilles and Naples, were Prince Mohamed Aly Pasha, Princess Chevekian Yousry, Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria, and many other well-known names, a complete list of which will be found in the list of passengers.

Herr von Mohl, German Member of the Public Debt Commission, has left Alexandria for Cairo. Mr. Farrall, the British Commiss- ioner, has arrived at Alexandria from Europe by the Austrian Lloyd steamer.

News from Naples of the Dean and Mrs. Butcher gives a good account of them, for they were enjoying a very smooth passage and already feeling much better for their change. They go to Genoa by sea and thence overland to Walensee.
Mr. G. D. Hornblower, inspector of the Ministry of the Interior, has been granted leave of absence from the 8th inst. until October 18th.
Adly Pasha Yaghen, president of the Wakfs Administration, will arrive in Cairo on the 4th prox. on his return from Europe.
One month's leave of absence has been accorded to El Kaimakam Shankat Bey, Com- mandant of Police, Behera Province.
An extension of twenty days’ leave of absence has been accorded to El Kaimakam Moustafa Tewfik Bey, who will resume his functions on the 11th inst.
El Naaman Omran Bey has been appointed president of the native tribunals at Assouan.

Mr. and Mrs Barns are staying at Church House until Tuesday, September 25th, and are at home every Saturday afternoon. After the 25th, their address will be Beyt Abdu Ghali- Kasr-el-Nuzha, Sharia Shoubra. To find the house, go along the Sharia Shoubra from the station and take the first turning to the left, passing a big, unfinithed-looking building, the Asile des Vieillards. Beyt Abdu is the second house on the right. The Asile des Vieillards is situated about 100 yards on the Cairo side of the Tewfikieh School

div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAYS.
ENGLISHMEN DISSATISFIED.
div.p: Considerable dissatisfaction is expressed among the Englishmen employed at the State Railway works at Boulac on account of the treatment to which some of their colleagues have been subjected. We understand that one Englishman, who has been in the railways for four years, has been dismissed the service on account of having missed four working days out of July, for two of which he gives indisposi- tion as his excuse and for the other two that there was no work for him to do. No notice that such strennuos-measures would be taken had, it is asserted, been given. Other English workmen have been fined for irregularity in keeping time.

A far graver charge is, however, brought against those who are responsible for this department It is stated that men are brought out to this country under the misapprehension that they will receive a fixed salary and that on the completion of a certain term of service will be made foremen, if their work is found to be satisfactory, whereas on their arrival they are put on piece-work, which means payment by time.
We understand that the dismissed English man to whom we refer above has placed his case in the hands of one of the best known lawyers of Cairo, and intends to dispute the legality of his dismissal.

div.head: QUESTIONS MUNICIPALES
UN DANGER PUBLIC
div.p: Depuis que le vent soulève les terres du quai, il doit bien y avoir on pied de terrasse- ment emporté de cùté et d'autre, dans les rues, dans les maisons, sur les toits, sur les habits et dans les poumons des passante. Ces terres prises sur l'emplacement d'an ciennes catacombes à Chatby ne sont antres que la cendre de millions de cadavres et momies entassés là par d'innombrables gêné- rations.
Or, d'après une découverte récente et sensa- tiousellè, la tuberculosi qui ravage actuelle- ment l’Europe et l'Amérique est attribuée par des savants art maniement des momies égyptiennes.

Dans de telles conditions, n'y a-t-il pas lieu de s'inquiéter et de rechercher si la tuber- culose qui fait de si rapides progrès à Alex andrie depuis quelques années, n'est pas dùe aux terrassements du quai, aux fouilles récentes et surtout à la dispersion par le vent aur toute la ville de cette terre suspecte? Une mesure d’urgence qui ne coûterait presque rien consisterait en un abondant arrosage une fois par semaine an moins des terrains do quai pour immobiliser cette poussière dangereuse.

div.head: CAILLAS ET BECFIOUBS
div.p: La chasse aux cailles a commencé. Des filets sont tendus un peu partout sur le rivage depuis Chatby jusqu'à la pointe d'Aboukir.

Eu dépit des mesures prises pour arrêter la destruction des becfigues en prohibant la chasse et la vente de ces précieux insectivores, on n'en continue pas moins à les consommer sur les tables privées et dans les restaurants. Des indigènes les colportent dissimulés sons leur galabieh et à voir leur air mystérieux et la façon dont ils chuchotent le nom de leur mer- chandise, on croirait des vendeurs de certaines cartes postales illustrées.

div.head: THE SPLENDID HOTELS
div.p: Plusieurs lecteurs nous ayant demandé des renseignements sur les résultats du premier exercice dee Splendid Hotels, yoici les infor- mations que noos avons pu obtenir : — Bien que les recettes se soient élevées à £22,000, les bénéfices nets n'ont été pendant Tannée dernière que do £1,500. Ces piètres résultats sont dût en partie à le mauvaise administration do directeur et en partie à la fermeture de l'hôtel pendant une grande partie de l’année à cause des additions qui y ont été laites.

L'exetoioe courant se présente haureasement- sous de meilleurs auspices. Eu effet, un nou- veau directeur de laplas haute compétence, M. Reinsperger, a été engagé pour le New Khe- divial Hotel sur la désignation de M. Baehler. L’hôtel est dono aujourd'hui exploité sur un pied économique.

Les 6.000 pics carrés de terrain et l'immeu- ble do New Khedivial Hotel ont été acquis par la Société de la famille Menasce au prix de L.E. 61,000. Les additions qui y ont été faites depuis ont ouûté près de L.E. 12,000. La valeur actuelle de la propriété sociale dépasse certainement le capital de la Société, qui est de Let. 90,000.

div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)
On constate une tendance prononcée à la hausse de la National Bank, qui gagne en- core 3/16 à 26 11/16.
Les Nungovich Hotels, après avoir atteint 18 1/16 durant la matinée, réactionnent en clôtore à 17 13/16-7/8, à la suite de quelques réalisations.
De 6 1/16 l'Urbaine a'avanoe à 6 3/16 ven- deurs.

Parmi les antres titres qui attirent l'atten- tion de la spéculation, il taut signaler l’Agri- cole qui gagne 1/32 à 9 23/32, la Cassa di Scouto 3/4 à 225 3/4, la Delta Land 1 /S8 à 3 3/8 et le Comptoir qui perd 1/32 à 6 23/32. En revanche, sa part de fondateur hausse d'une livre à 46.
Le Trust et les Building Lands remontent à 1 7/16 et 5 1/16 respectivement Eu général on croit que l'asscmblée dé ce soir des Buil- ding Lands ratifiera définitivement la fusion des deux sociétés.

div.head: Circulaire H: De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: La Caire, 3 Septembre.

Le taux de l’escompte libre à Londres se maintient à 3 1/2 poor cent. Au Stock Ex- change, le Consolidé anglais a haussé de 1/8 vendredi et d'autant samedi, à 87 8/4. L’Uni- fiés est restée invariée à 104 3'4, de même quo la National Bank à 26 3/8. L’Agricole a re- gagné 1/8 samedi à 9 7/8 La Daira a rattrapé, à 16 7/8, le- huitième qu'elle avait perdu la veille. La Delta Light a repris également 1/8 vendredi à 11 3/4
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a avancé sàmedi à 762. La Banque d'Athènes est demeurée inchangée à 141.

Ici, le marché des valeurs a montré, ce matin, de fort bonnes dispositions. La tendance géné- rale était à la fermeté. Plusieurs titres ont acquis one avance notable ; le cours d'autres valeurs s'est sensiblement raffermi.

La National Bank a débuté à 26 5/16 pour clôturer à 26 7/16-1/2. L’Agricole a progressé à
9 11/16 3/4. La Cassa di Sconto a gagné 4 francs à 226 ; l’action nouvelle s’est à son tour, inscrite à 218 219. La Banque d'Athènes s’est alourdie à 1(1. Le Comptoir Financier a été poussé à 6 11/16 3/4 l’actioa ancienne et 6 1/2-9/16 la nouvelle ; la part de fondateur a été traitée à 46 47. La Banque d'Abyssinie est revenue à 5 7/8.
Le Crédit Foncier a avancé de 6 francs à 739 760. L’action Immobilière a fait 390-391 et la part de fondateur 748 750. L'action Wardan Estate a atteint £7 et la part de fondateur 8 5/8.
La part de fondateur Agricole do Nil a été échangée à 7 3/16-1/4.

Les Héiopolis sont restés à 319 ; la part de fondateur à 8 3/4. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont été offertes à 262. Les Automobiles se sont raffermies à 5 1/16. La part de fonda- teur Menzaleh a reculé à 100.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich, mouvementés, ont avancé à 17 3/4-13/16. Les Egyptian se maintenus à 6 3/8. Les Upper Egypt ont été cotés à 4 13/16-7/8

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont clôturé à3 5/16 3/8. Les Estates ont.été large- ment échangés à l 13/16 7/8 ; la para de fonda- teur a bénéficié de /32 à 11 11/16. Les Walker and Meimarachiont molli à £0 5/8-11/16 et les Hookerà 0 7/8-15/16. Les Sucreries ont été négociées à 24 francs.
On nous écrit d'Alexandrie, à la date d'hier:

“L'entente est complète, absolue, entre les administrateurs de la Building Lands Co. et ceux de l’Egyptian Trust and Investment Ltd. (Glymenopoulo), tous les dissentiments étant désormais apaisés. Il se peut dono qu'à l'as- semblée de mardi 4 Septembre (si toutefois les actions représentées forment les 3/4 du capital exigés par les statuts) la fusion soit définitive- ment ratifiée et à l'unanimité.

“Ce qui a fortemeut contribué a mettre l bon accord est l'abandon par le Trust d'nne somme de 24,GOJ livres sur les 32,000 qui doivent être employées à indemniser certains intéressés ; cela représente pre-qoe 1/2 livre par action Building. Il y a donc tontes les chances pour que cette différence d'une demi livre soit escomptés en Bourse par une hausse sur le cours des actions.”
Suivant des informations d’Athènes, la répartition des actions nouvelles de la Banque d'Athènei se ferait sur les bases suivantes:
Les souscripteurs de 1 à 15 actions rece- vraient la totalié de leur demande ; an-dessus de 15, les souscripteurs recevraient le 65%.
La formation d’une nouvelle Société Ano- nyme pour l'Egypte a été enregistrée le 29 Août à Londres sons la dénomination de “Caflari's Cooperative Markets.”
Le genre de cette Société coopérative est tout nouveau pour l'Egypte, car actionnaires et clients auront leur part de bénéfices.
M. Caffari, administrateur délégué, est at- tendu le 14 do courant an Caire, venant d'Eu- rope, où il a visité les principaux établissements similaires, tels que ceux de Londres, Milan, etc.
Les actionnaires de la Société Anonyme des Chemins de fer de la Buse-Egypte sont convo- qués en assembléegéuérale ordinaire le 3 Octo- bre prochain, au siège social à Bruxelles.
Ordre du jour: rapports du conseil d’adminis- tration et des commissaires ; bilan et comptes des profits et pertes de l'exercice 1905 1906; nomination d'administrateurs et de commis- saires.
Les recettes de la Dalta Light Railways Co- pour la semaine au 25 août sa sont élevées à L.E. 4,285 contre 3,751 en 1905, soit en aug- mentation de L.E. 714.
Les recettes total is depuis le 1er Avril ont atteint la somme de L.B 81,123 contre 75 068, soit en plus-value de LE. 6,051 pour l’e- xercice courant.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex- pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all to permit-within certain necessary limits- free discussion.
PURIFICATION OF ALEXANDRIA.
To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette".

Sir, -In reference to “J.P.'s" letter I beg to state that we have already adopted the system he advocates, and we are continually lending back the young women. In tact two men are employed at Alexandria who board every boat arriving here for the very purpose. The system has been at work for the last two years, although your correspondent ap- pears to be "quite ignorant of the fact. As to the personal remarks on my humble self, which your Cairo Correspondent indulges in, I herewith submit the following sketch of my life and labours:—

About 26 years ago the Presbyterians out here who had already a missionary to the Jews here, who however did not do very much work, thought it worth their while to have a con- verted Jew here instead. As knowing the ian- guage well, the Hebrew religion, the ins and outs of the Jewish people, snob as their man- ners and customs, and above all the failings of their religion compared to the Bible, was a good idea, as he could preach the gospel in spirit and in truth and convince the Jews of their mistake as owing to his hitherto being a Jew he could more readily and convincingly tell them. Consequently they authorised the Head Man of the Jewish Mission to find a converted Jew Missionary, but as he was unable to find one in Egypt or Palestine, the converted Jews and all the Missionaries in Palestine advised him to write to London and ask for Peter Rudolph. The Head Missionary therefore went in person and asked the London Society Mission for me. As I was always out- side working he could not see me, so he saw Bishop Barclay, who was very loath to lose me as he wanted me under his care as a mission- ary, and he did not want to let me go. How- ever as I was far from strong, having suffered ill health with hard work and London fogs, the Bishop kindly allowed me three months leave, he himself informing the Head Missionary that he would only lend me to him during my sojourn in Jerusalem until I recover- ed. Before I left London I found when travelling through my district that a cer- tain party had been making enquiries about we, as to my leaving them and all my poor people cried out in alarm saying : Oh! don’t take Mr. Rudolph,” he is one of the best workers we have ever had. It turned out that it had been the Head Mis- sionary to the Jews who had been making these enquiries indirectly, and on my coming across him in the street I did not know who he was until he told me. I asked him “Why do you select me of others?”—“Because I have been advised by other missionaries in Egypt and Palestine to do so and I myself have watched your endeavours amongst the poor here how you have tried although suffer- ing in ill health yourself to help poor suffering humanity both physically and spiritually and it is the most heartfelt wish of the Mis- sionaries after your rest to go to Alexandria and preach the word of God to the Jews. Now think of it and say, “Yes” I loved the people I had been working among and it was only after due consideration that I consented to undertake the duty. After my rest in Jerusalem I eventually arrived in Alex- andria on the 1st April (All Fools Day) which happened to be on an Easter Sunday. On my arrival here upon terra incognita, I was greatly dissappointed, for there was no one there to meet me,I was alone, no friend to welcome me and in a foreign country.
A Shocking Discovery.

Eventually an Arab seeing me,took me ashore and brought me to an hotel. I washed myself and came down to breakfast, whereon I saw two lovely young women, the build and the completion of whom I guessed to be English. I was not mistaken, as during breakfast one said to the other "I think this gentleman is English and a Minister of the Gospel, it is not right by any means for Madame not to inform him what sort of a house this is.” This natur- ally made me look askance and on my enquir- ing their reasons they told me that all the girls in that house were “kept" women. I trembled. Could it be possible that these two young English girls had sold both their bodies and souls to the devil? I prayed inwardly and asked God to help me to rescue them.
Rescuing Girls.

During conversation with them, one-of-them said she was the daughter of an English clergyman and they could not possibly go home to their country, as the gentlemen (or beasts I should say) paid them their hotel bill and only allowed them £2 or £3 a month pocket money. I was so horrified that I paid their passage home and had a latter of rejoic- ing and gladness from both the clergyman and daughter thanking me for what find done. This was the first instance of girls being rescu- ed from the White Slave Traffic in Alexandria, and I thank God that I was the pioneer of the movement That was 28 years ago, since which time I have, by God’s help, saved dozens from a life of shame and immorality. For years I had no one to help me as it is only during the last two years a Society has been formed through my endeavours to pot a stop to this White Slave Traffic ; but more of this later.
Girls’ Hard Struggle.

Before I came to Alexindria governoresses and other girls had a hard struggle, as they generally came on pot lock without any situa- tion to go to. Thera was no public home to go to, to seek shelter, advice and guidance. When their money was finished, nothing was left but the streets ; such has been the case of many. I did my best for them but what is one amongst
so many. When I became known every one used to flock to me and I was continually asking my friends and even going from house to house endeavouring to find employment for these girls as I knew if I could not it was only in God’s hands how their future life would be spent
A Terrible Story.

I remember one instance of many painful ones in my memory of a certain Scotch girl. I believe she came from Cyprus, and she was recommended to me by Mr. Whitfield who took great interest in her. I recommended her to an English drapery store in Cherif Pasha-st, who placed her in a highly respectable Greek family. This Scotch girl was so gifted that within three months she turned all the naughty children into angels, the Greek lady was so pleased with her that when Xmas came round she presented her with a lovely gold watch and new dresses to the value of £20, but un- fortunately this girl was in the habit of taking a drop too much and one day she asked to be away to enable her to see her uncle, a well- known English resident here. Instead of going to see him she went to a grocer’s where she got intoxicated and 5’or 6 days afterwards she was seen in a Bedouin s tent with only her shirt on. As there was no public Home for her to go to she was found in a chemist shop dressed in this attire, a wreck of one of the smartest and most intelligent girls one could come across. The chemist knowing that I looked after these poor suffering mortals left her in my hands.
Mrs. Sheldon Amos.

Mrs. Sheldon Amos kept her in her home for a fortnight I saw the late Canon Davies of St. Mark's Church and Mrs. Sheldon Amos and I eventually got this poor unfortunate sent away, or else she would have become a white slave, not having a “home" where to seek advice or a “refuge." This set me thinking and I asked Mrs. Sheldon Amos, what could be done as a protection to these girls. I told her we most have a Home and the money would come. We went to Sir Charles Cookson, the British Consul,and on hearing what we wanted he held both hands up to heaven and said "God grant us such a Home, and a Home, Mr. Rudolph, we shall have."
Home for Girls.

After consultation, Mrs. Amos and I went to the late Canon Davies of St. Marks Church then to the Minister of the German Church, as well as the Deaconess Sister Barbara. They all agreed most enthusiastically to my project; the latter immediately promised 6 bedsteads for the Home. Mrs. Amos went to the Scotch Minister and asked his support but she could not get his approval. Shortly after this she was called to Germany to see her family and I was left alone to battle for the very such needed “home,” For nearly 6 weeks those interested in the undertaking used to meet in my house to talk matters over, even including a Member of the Scotch Church, and it was appointed that an English lady called Mac Dougall and a Swiss Lady Gobelli should superintend the "Home" when it was obtained.
Scotch Intrigues.

A short time after this these two ladies came to my house in a great rage and said “After all your promises you have sold us it is just as we thought ; Pot no trust in a Jew.’” "Why, why," I exclaimed. Those Scotch people, who pretended not to approve of the movement for a Home for governesses and who said it would not work but yet who came to your house like spies and found ont everything you were going to do have now gone and rented a house and asked Sister Barbara for the 6 beds she had promised you, saying you had given the matter up. Is it true?” This took the breath out of me. I have never given the pro- ject up and never even thought of doing so but I will make enquiries. I did and what I had heard was only too true. They had taken the leading strings out of my hand. On my forcing them to show their hand why they claim- ed to be the instigators of the Victoria House, their excuse was as ridiculous as it is as easy to drink water. One of their members has a relation in Europe, and she sent some cir- culars out here about the Home where she is matron for girls "But,” I explained, “that house has nothing to do with the one here, its Direc- tors are not the same, its rules and conditions are not the same; how in the world can you say that this Victoria House was established by you.” It pleased them to think so, so I let them think but as every one admitted, it was decidedly underhand, and probably it was through this that the Home did not last long. They never went about the thing in a proper, business like open handed manner, consequen- tly the British Community rose and took it out of their hands, and since then it has done good work. This ends the report of the Victoria Home.
Victoria House.

The Home for fallen girls had never left my mind ; my mind was fixed upon having two Homes, one for governesses, &c. to keep them from going to the bad, and to try and get them work. The Victoria House was the result. Now the other Home was for fallen girls, to try to keep them good daring the time I was getting the respective Consulates to send them home to their own country. Several visitors who held good positions in their countries always told me that they would use their influence when they got home to try and assist me in getting a Home going and suitable enough for the purpose, bat these promises never came to anything for I never heard any- thing farther. Claude Montefiore Esq. came to Egypt to see if anything could be done to help these poor down-trodden women, so he went to Cairo and every one told him that the only one who could give any assistance and who already knew everything about these girls was Mr. Rudolph.
The Home Founded.

He came to my house in Alexandria and was presented to me by Baron Menasce. They asked me for advice, so I willingly told them
that what was the most important thing of all was to obtain a house, a long treasured idea of mine, as the work could not be properly carried out without one. Another thing I proposed was to invite all the Consulates as well as the Governor of Alexandria to have a meeting at Baron Menacoe’s House. This was done and the matter was thoroughly thrashed out, whereon Baron Menasce said: "We will get one or two hundred pounds together and follow Mr. Rudoloph’s advice and obtain a Home for these poor girls." The Meeting had the entire support of the Consols. I got Lord Cromer, and Colonel Hopkinson, of the City Police, to interest themselves in the work and they assisted me very much in my arduous work. For my own part I have every treason to be thankful and grateful for the success of the works of which I have been the originator and it was with the greatest pain and sorrow that I withdrew my name from this Society as it was utterly impossible for me to assist, help, aid, and give my wide experience of the work,—years longer than any on else on the Committee,—when it was so grossly mis- managed.
PETER RUDOLPH.
The Rudolph Home,
September 1st, 1906.

div.head: MALTA HARBOUR WORKS
div.p: In anticipation of the storms which often occur at Malta even early in October, the con- struction of the Imperial breakwater is being prosecuted with great activity at the present moment. Day and night the work goes on apase. The shorter arm, 400ft. in length, is already completely finished, and the staging is all remo- ved. The longer, or northern, arm, which will be three times as long as the other, and will have to withstand the full force of the sets hauled towards the port by the fierce "grigale” winds, is being pushed out sensibly month by month. The construction of the breakwater was to have taken six years. Three have elapsed since the inception of the works, and the contractors, Messrs. Pearson and Son, are relatively in advance of the stipulated time with their undertaking.

div.head: A NEW SYRIAN PATRIARCH.
div.p: Ignatius Abd-il Massech has been elected patriarch of the Syrian Jacobite Church. The Sublime Porte has accepted the choice. There are fourteen Bishops within this Jacobite Pa- triarchate. Three of them hold posts in India.

Ignatius Abd-il Massech was born on Octo- ber 21st, 1836, in Syria. He assumed the vows of a monk in Jerusalem during 1856, from which life he was removed to Orfa, Mesopota- mia He was ordained deacon in 1864, and priest in 1867. In 1873 he travelled with his Patriarch to London, were they were received by Queen Victoria. After visiting India, where he preached in 184 churches, be returned to Emesa, and acted as the Patriarch's secretary. In 1884 he revisited England, where he spent one year and nine months. He speaks English fluently. On his return to Emesa he brought with him printing and book-binding machines. He is beloved by his flock, who are delighted at his appointment

div.head: THE PREMIER’ RETORT
div.p: An old lady who has been in the habit of meeting Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman at Marienbad was, a morning paper states, parti- cularly effusive in her compliments when she met him there for the first time this year. Her absolute frankness is one of her characteristics. “I had no idea last year," she said, "that you were likely to be Prime Minister. My friends told me you were simply a warming pan for Lord Rosebery." "Scotsmen never make good warming pans," was the Premier's reply.

div.head: THE CZAR'S ONLY WAY.
div.p: The way to prevent revolution is by giving reform, but the Czar has long ago let the time for prevention pass. All that can now be ex- pected is to prevent the revolution from be- coming ever more and more bloody and anarchical, by opening the safety valve and by winning over the moderate reformers from any sort of sympathy with the terrorists. We have heard much in manifestoes of the "inflexi- ble will" of the Czar as a reformer. The one thing instantly needed is the realisation of that will in actjon.—“Chronicle”

div.head: DANGERS OF RAW FRUIT.
div.p: Professor Metchnikof, the famous bacterio- logist, declares that raw fruit should never be eaten. He condemns it beyond remission, says the Paris correspondent of the “Tele- graph," Asked whether grape pips may not give appendicitis, he though that they might, but considered that a detail. The essential point is that microbes swarm on all fruit of whatsoever kind. On the other hand, he recommends stewed fruit warmly, as it is p alatable, wholesome, and sterilised by boiling.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
FOOTBALL.
ROYAL INNISKILL1NG FUSILIERS CORPORALS. RIGHT HALF BATTALION. LEFT HALF BATTALION.
div.p: The football season was ushered in on Wednesday evening last, when corporals representing the above met in a friendly en- counter. It was of great interest to see that old veteran, Corporal Aiken, don the shirt again. At the appointed time for starting the Referee, Walsh, lined his men out in the order men- tioned: Right, half Battalion, Goal, Aitken; Backs, Elliot and Casey; half books, Millen,Cole and Irvine; forwards, Presley, Locks, Colline, Parke, and Conaghin. Left half Battalion, Goal Heaney; Backsc Carey and Murphy; half backs McLoughlin, MoCristoll and Brag; forwards, Montgomery, Millar, Russel, McGoniagle.

About 500 spectators were present when the Referee’s whistle announced time for hostilities to commence, the left half at once got agoing, but Casey returned, and Collins got possession. He was, however, robbed when nearing the scoring point, shortly alter Cole gave Keaney a hot ‘un to hold, which he saved well. Still the right half pressed, and Keaney was beaten at close range amid cheers. On resuming McGonigale and Russell were seen to advantage, but all to no purpose, as Aitken came in their road, time after-time. Presley now made a good ran, giving the sphere to Collins. The latter had a shot which missed by inches. Give and take was now the order for some time until Collins got away in good style and binding all opposition be scored number two. The left half now woke up and Russel getting the sphere made tracks for Aitken, but the latter was not to be caught napping, his splendid "saves” being a treat to watch. Play after this was of a even nature. A good break away by Locke was the means of bringing play down towards Murphy and com- pany, where Collins when in a good position was given offside. About two minutes later the same player had a splendid chance of increas- ing the score when he shot sky-high over the bar. The right half were now pressing for all they were worth and Keaney and company had their work cut out to prevent a farther score. Shortly after they succeeded in adding to their score. Urged on by their supporters, the left half went off at a rattling pace towards Aitken where they secured a corner off Elliot. This was well taken by McGonigale, but McCristo sent behind. On the kick-off Montgomery got away, a scrimmage ensued in which Russel getting the sphere close in had no trouble in recording the first goal for his side.
This was all the scoring in this half and, hal time found the score.
Right half Battalion 3 goals.
Left half Battalion 1 goal.

The second moiety was begun by Russel, and the first item, of any importance was a good sprint by Presley. Twice in sucess- sion were the right half within a point of scoring, but skying the ball spoiled all efforts. A handbell against the left half put their opponents in a good position, but over eagerness spoiled all attempts. McGonigale was now seen to advantage and he shot when well placed, but he had the mortification of seeing the ball glance off the upright. The left half were now pressing well, and McGonigale, alter futile efforts, beat Aitken all ends up. Midfield play now followed, and the right half got away per Collins, and Cole with a well judged shot bought the total to 4 to 2. Some exciting play took place around Aitken, but the veteran was amply unbeatable. Still the right halt scored again per Collins. The left half now realised their position and they got close to Aitken who had to look out for his Ps and Q. Excite- ment was now great as Russel missed by inches towards the end of this half. The left half se- ared two more goals the last one being scored one minute from time. Full time score
Right half Battalion 5 goals.
Left half Battalion 4 goals.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria ,Damanhour, Tantah, Zagazig, or Saida Zenab.
